Description: Mould-made disc-shaped scaraboid or game-piece in glazed composition; slightly domed back with straight sides; underside flat with no decoration; not pierced; in white paste; unglazed (said to be unbaked and unglazed on the EEF distribution list).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

This piece could be an unfinished disc-shaped scaraboid. The "Scarab Factory" in Naukratis produced lots of this type of scaraboids (on its various productions, see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming), usually with incised decoration on the underside and pierced. This is also what is suggested in the EEF distribution list for Boston: "flat surface left blank - specimen of clay pressed in mould, and not yet handed over to the "scarab-cutter". Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.055) (phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4912 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
